trans-unit.source: Premium Storage: High-Performance Storage for Azure Virtual Machine Workloads | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage: High-Performance Storage for Azure Virtual Machine Workloads | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn Azure Premium Storage for Disks.
trans-unit.target: Learn Azure Premium Storage for Disks.

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a Premium Storage account.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a Premium Storage account.

trans-unit.source: Premium Storage: High-Performance Storage for Azure Virtual Machine Workloads
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage: High-Performance Storage for Azure Virtual Machine Workloads

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: Welcome to **Azure Premium Storage Disks** for faster Azure virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Welcome to **Azure Premium Storage Disks** for faster Azure virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: With the introduction of Premium Storage, Microsoft Azure now offers two types of durable storage: **Premium Storage** and **Standard Storage**.
trans-unit.target: With the introduction of Premium Storage, Microsoft Azure now offers two types of durable storage: **Premium Storage** and **Standard Storage**.

trans-unit.source: Premium Storage stores data on the latest technology Solid State Drives (SSDs) whereas Standard Storage stores data on Hard Disk Drives (HDDs).
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage stores data on the latest technology Solid State Drives (SSDs) whereas Standard Storage stores data on Hard Disk Drives (HDDs).

trans-unit.source: Premium Storage delivers high-performance, low-latency disk support for I/O intensive workloads running on Azure Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage delivers high-performance, low-latency disk support for I/O intensive workloads running on Azure Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: You can attach several Premium Storage disks to a virtual machine (VM).
trans-unit.target: You can attach several Premium Storage disks to a virtual machine (VM).

trans-unit.source: With Premium Storage, your applications can have up to 64 TB of storage per VM and achieve 80,000 IOPS (input/output operations per second) per VM and 2000 MB per second disk throughput per VM with extremely low latencies for read operations.
trans-unit.target: With Premium Storage, your applications can have up to 64 TB of storage per VM and achieve 80,000 IOPS (input/output operations per second) per VM and 2000 MB per second disk throughput per VM with extremely low latencies for read operations.

trans-unit.source: To get started with Azure Premium Storage, visit [Get started for free](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/) page.
trans-unit.target: To get started with Azure Premium Storage, visit [Get started for free](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/) page.

trans-unit.source: This article provides an in-depth overview of Azure Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: This article provides an in-depth overview of Azure Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: Important Things to Know About Premium Storage
trans-unit.target: Important Things to Know About Premium Storage

trans-unit.source: The following is a list of important things to consider before or when using Premium Storage:
trans-unit.target: The following is a list of important things to consider before or when using Premium Storage:

trans-unit.source: To use Premium Storage, you need to have a Premium Storage account.
trans-unit.target: To use Premium Storage, you need to have a Premium Storage account.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to create a Premium Storage account, see [Creating and using Premium Storage Account for Disks](#create-and-use-a-premium-storage-account-for-a-virtual-machine-data-disk).
trans-unit.target: To learn how to create a Premium Storage account, see [Creating and using Premium Storage Account for Disks](#create-and-use-a-premium-storage-account-for-a-virtual-machine-data-disk).

trans-unit.source: Premium Storage is currently available in the [Microsoft Azure Preview Portal](https://portal.azure.com/) and accessible via the following SDK libraries: [Storage REST API](http://msdn.microsoft.com//library/azure/dd179355.aspx) version 2014-02-14 or later; [Service Management REST API](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee460799.aspx) version 2014-10-01 or later; and [Azure PowerShell](../install-configure-powershell.md) version 0.8.10 or later.
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage is currently available in the [Microsoft Azure Preview Portal](https://portal.azure.com/) and accessible via the following SDK libraries: [Storage REST API](http://msdn.microsoft.com//library/azure/dd179355.aspx) version 2014-02-14 or later; [Service Management REST API](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee460799.aspx) version 2014-10-01 or later; and [Azure PowerShell](../install-configure-powershell.md) version 0.8.10 or later.

trans-unit.source: For a list of regions that currently support Premium Storage, see [Azure Services by Region](http://azure.microsoft.com/regions/#services).
trans-unit.target: For a list of regions that currently support Premium Storage, see [Azure Services by Region](http://azure.microsoft.com/regions/#services).

trans-unit.source: Premium Storage supports only Azure page blobs, which are used to hold persistent disks for Azure Virtual Machines (VMs).
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage supports only Azure page blobs, which are used to hold persistent disks for Azure Virtual Machines (VMs).

trans-unit.source: For information on Azure page blobs, see [Understanding Block Blobs and Page Blobs](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee691964.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For information on Azure page blobs, see [Understanding Block Blobs and Page Blobs](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee691964.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Premium Storage does not support the Azure Block Blobs, Azure Files, Azure Tables, or Azure Queues.
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage does not support the Azure Block Blobs, Azure Files, Azure Tables, or Azure Queues.

trans-unit.source: A Premium Storage account is locally redundant (LRS) and keeps three copies of the data within a single region.
trans-unit.target: A Premium Storage account is locally redundant (LRS) and keeps three copies of the data within a single region.

trans-unit.source: For considerations regarding geo replication when using Premium Storage, see the [Snapshots and Copy Blob when using Premium Storage](#snapshots-and-copy-blob-when-using-premium-storage) section in this article.
trans-unit.target: For considerations regarding geo replication when using Premium Storage, see the [Snapshots and Copy Blob when using Premium Storage](#snapshots-and-copy-blob-when-using-premium-storage) section in this article.

trans-unit.source: If you want to use a Premium Storage account for your VM disks, you need to use the DS-series or GS-series of VMs.
trans-unit.target: If you want to use a Premium Storage account for your VM disks, you need to use the DS-series or GS-series of VMs.

trans-unit.source: You can use both Standard and Premium storage disks with DS-series or GS-series of VMs.
trans-unit.target: You can use both Standard and Premium storage disks with DS-series or GS-series of VMs.

trans-unit.source: But you cannot use Premium Storage disks with non-DS-series or non-GS-series of VMs.
trans-unit.target: But you cannot use Premium Storage disks with non-DS-series or non-GS-series of VMs.

trans-unit.source: For information on available Azure VM disk types and sizes, see [Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn197896.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For information on available Azure VM disk types and sizes, see [Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn197896.aspx).

trans-unit.source: The process for setting up Premium Storage disks for a VM is similar to Standard Storage disks.
trans-unit.target: The process for setting up Premium Storage disks for a VM is similar to Standard Storage disks.

trans-unit.source: You need to choose the most appropriate Premium Storage option for your Azure disks and VM.
trans-unit.target: You need to choose the most appropriate Premium Storage option for your Azure disks and VM.

trans-unit.source: The VM size should be suitable for your workload based on the performance characteristics of the Premium offerings.
trans-unit.target: The VM size should be suitable for your workload based on the performance characteristics of the Premium offerings.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage](#scalability-and-performance-targets-when-using-premium-storage).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage](#scalability-and-performance-targets-when-using-premium-storage).

trans-unit.source: A premium storage account cannot be mapped to a custom domain name.
trans-unit.target: A premium storage account cannot be mapped to a custom domain name.

trans-unit.source: Storage analytics is not currently supported for Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: Storage analytics is not currently supported for Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: To analyze the performance metrics of VMs using disks on Premium Storage accounts, use the operating system based tools, such as [Windows Performance Monitor](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc749249.aspx) for Windows VMs and [IOSTAT](http://linux.die.net/man/1/iostat) for Linux VMs.
trans-unit.target: To analyze the performance metrics of VMs using disks on Premium Storage accounts, use the operating system based tools, such as [Windows Performance Monitor](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc749249.aspx) for Windows VMs and [IOSTAT](http://linux.die.net/man/1/iostat) for Linux VMs.

trans-unit.source: You can also enable the Azure VM Diagnostics on Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: You can also enable the Azure VM Diagnostics on Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: Refer to [Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine Monitoring with Azure Diagnostics Extension](http://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/09/02/windows-azure-virtual-machine-monitoring-with-wad-extension/) for details.
trans-unit.target: Refer to [Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine Monitoring with Azure Diagnostics Extension](http://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/09/02/windows-azure-virtual-machine-monitoring-with-wad-extension/) for details.

trans-unit.source: Using Premium Storage for Disks
trans-unit.target: Using Premium Storage for Disks

trans-unit.source: You can use Premium Storage for Disks in one of two ways:
trans-unit.target: You can use Premium Storage for Disks in one of two ways:

trans-unit.source: Create a new premium storage account first and then use it when creating the VM.
trans-unit.target: Create a new premium storage account first and then use it when creating the VM.

trans-unit.source: Create a new DS-series or GS-series VM.
trans-unit.target: Create a new DS-series or GS-series VM.

trans-unit.source: While creating the VM, you can select a previously created Premium Storage account, create a new one, or let the Azure Portal to create a default premium account.
trans-unit.target: While creating the VM, you can select a previously created Premium Storage account, create a new one, or let the Azure Portal to create a default premium account.

trans-unit.source: Azure uses the storage account as a container for your operating system (OS) and data disks.
trans-unit.target: Azure uses the storage account as a container for your operating system (OS) and data disks.

trans-unit.source: In other words, if you create an Azure DS-series or GS-series VM and select an Azure Premium Storage account, your operating system and data disks are stored in that storage account.
trans-unit.target: In other words, if you create an Azure DS-series or GS-series VM and select an Azure Premium Storage account, your operating system and data disks are stored in that storage account.

trans-unit.source: To leverage the benefits of Premium Storage, create a Premium Storage account using an account type of *Premium_LRS* first.
trans-unit.target: To leverage the benefits of Premium Storage, create a Premium Storage account using an account type of *Premium_LRS* first.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you can use the [Microsoft Azure Preview Portal](https://portal.azure.com/), [Azure PowerShell](../install-configure-powershell.md), or the [Service Management REST API](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee460799.aspx).
trans-unit.target: To do this, you can use the [Microsoft Azure Preview Portal](https://portal.azure.com/), [Azure PowerShell](../install-configure-powershell.md), or the [Service Management REST API](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee460799.aspx).

trans-unit.source: For step-by-step instructions, see [Creating and using Premium Storage Account for Disks](#create-and-use-a-premium-storage-account-for-a-virtual-machine-data-disk).
trans-unit.target: For step-by-step instructions, see [Creating and using Premium Storage Account for Disks](#create-and-use-a-premium-storage-account-for-a-virtual-machine-data-disk).

trans-unit.source: Important notes:
trans-unit.target: Important notes:

trans-unit.source: For details about the capacity and bandwidth limits for Premium Storage accounts, see the [Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage](#scalability-and-performance-targets-when-using-premium-storage) section.
trans-unit.target: For details about the capacity and bandwidth limits for Premium Storage accounts, see the [Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage](#scalability-and-performance-targets-when-using-premium-storage) section.

trans-unit.source: If the needs of your application exceed the scalability targets of a single storage account, build your application to use multiple storage accounts, and partition your data across those storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: If the needs of your application exceed the scalability targets of a single storage account, build your application to use multiple storage accounts, and partition your data across those storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you want to attach 51 terabytes (TB) disks across a number of VMs, spread them across two storage accounts since 35 TB is the limit for a single Premium storage account.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you want to attach 51 terabytes (TB) disks across a number of VMs, spread them across two storage accounts since 35 TB is the limit for a single Premium storage account.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that a single Premium Storage account has never more than 35 TB of provisioned disks.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that a single Premium Storage account has never more than 35 TB of provisioned disks.

trans-unit.source: By default, disk caching policy is "Read-Only" for all the Premium data disks, and "Read-Write" for the Premium operating system disk attached to the VM.
trans-unit.target: By default, disk caching policy is "Read-Only" for all the Premium data disks, and "Read-Write" for the Premium operating system disk attached to the VM.

trans-unit.source: This configuration setting is recommended to achieve the optimal performance for your application’s I/Os.
trans-unit.target: This configuration setting is recommended to achieve the optimal performance for your application’s I/Os.

trans-unit.source: For write-heavy or write-only data disks (such as SQL Server log files), disable disk caching so that you can achieve better application performance.
trans-unit.target: For write-heavy or write-only data disks (such as SQL Server log files), disable disk caching so that you can achieve better application performance.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that there is sufficient bandwidth available on your VM to drive the disk traffic.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that there is sufficient bandwidth available on your VM to drive the disk traffic.

trans-unit.source: For example, a STANDARD_DS1 VM has 32 MB per second dedicated bandwidth available for Premium Storage disk traffic.
trans-unit.target: For example, a STANDARD_DS1 VM has 32 MB per second dedicated bandwidth available for Premium Storage disk traffic.

trans-unit.source: That means, a P10 Premium Storage disk attached to this VM can only go up to 32 MB per second but not up to 100 MB per second that the P10 disk can provide.
trans-unit.target: That means, a P10 Premium Storage disk attached to this VM can only go up to 32 MB per second but not up to 100 MB per second that the P10 disk can provide.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, a STANDARD_DS13 VM can go up to 256 MB per second across all disks.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, a STANDARD_DS13 VM can go up to 256 MB per second across all disks.

trans-unit.source: Currently, the largest VM on DS-series is STANDARD_DS14 and it can provide up to 512 MB per second across all disks.
trans-unit.target: Currently, the largest VM on DS-series is STANDARD_DS14 and it can provide up to 512 MB per second across all disks.

trans-unit.source: The largest VM on GS-series is STANDARD_GS5 and it can give up to 2000 MB per second across all disks.
trans-unit.target: The largest VM on GS-series is STANDARD_GS5 and it can give up to 2000 MB per second across all disks.

trans-unit.source: Note that these limits are for disk traffic alone, not including cache-hits and network traffic.
trans-unit.target: Note that these limits are for disk traffic alone, not including cache-hits and network traffic.

trans-unit.source: There is a separate bandwidth available for VM network traffic, which is different from the dedicated bandwidth for Premium Storage disks.
trans-unit.target: There is a separate bandwidth available for VM network traffic, which is different from the dedicated bandwidth for Premium Storage disks.

trans-unit.source: For the most up-to-date information on maximum IOPS and throughput (bandwidth) for DS-series and GS-series VMs, see [Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn197896.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For the most up-to-date information on maximum IOPS and throughput (bandwidth) for DS-series and GS-series VMs, see [Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn197896.aspx).

trans-unit.source: To learn about the Premium storage disks and their IOPs and throughput limits, see the table in the [Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage](#scalability-and-performance-targets-when-using-premium-storage) section in this article.
trans-unit.target: To learn about the Premium storage disks and their IOPs and throughput limits, see the table in the [Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage](#scalability-and-performance-targets-when-using-premium-storage) section in this article.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Cache-hits are not limited by the allocated IOPS/Throughput of the disk.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Cache-hits are not limited by the allocated IOPS/Throughput of the disk.

trans-unit.source: That is, when you use a data disk with ReadOnly cache setting on a DS-series VM or GS-series VM, Reads that are served from the cache are not subject to Premium Storage disk limits.
trans-unit.target: That is, when you use a data disk with ReadOnly cache setting on a DS-series VM or GS-series VM, Reads that are served from the cache are not subject to Premium Storage disk limits.

trans-unit.source: Hence you could get very high throughput from a disk if the workload is predominantly Reads.
trans-unit.target: Hence you could get very high throughput from a disk if the workload is predominantly Reads.

trans-unit.source: Note that, cache is subject to separate IOPS / Throughput limits at VM level based on the VM size.
trans-unit.target: Note that, cache is subject to separate IOPS / Throughput limits at VM level based on the VM size.

trans-unit.source: DS-series VMs have roughly 4000 IOPS and 33 MB/sec per core for cache and local SSD IOs.
trans-unit.target: DS-series VMs have roughly 4000 IOPS and 33 MB/sec per core for cache and local SSD IOs.

trans-unit.source: You can use both Premium and Standard storage disks in the same DS-series VM or GS-series VM.
trans-unit.target: You can use both Premium and Standard storage disks in the same DS-series VM or GS-series VM.

trans-unit.source: With Premium Storage, you can provision a DS-series VM and attach several persistent data disks to a VM.
trans-unit.target: With Premium Storage, you can provision a DS-series VM and attach several persistent data disks to a VM.

trans-unit.source: If needed, you can stripe across the disks to increase the capacity and performance of the volume.
trans-unit.target: If needed, you can stripe across the disks to increase the capacity and performance of the volume.

trans-unit.source: If you stripe Premium Storage data disks using [Storage Spaces](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh831739.aspx), you should configure it with one column for each disk that is used.
trans-unit.target: If you stripe Premium Storage data disks using [Storage Spaces](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh831739.aspx), you should configure it with one column for each disk that is used.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, overall performance of the striped volume may be lower than expected due to uneven distribution of traffic across the disks.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, overall performance of the striped volume may be lower than expected due to uneven distribution of traffic across the disks.

trans-unit.source: By default, the Server Manager user interface (UI) allows you to setup columns up to 8 disks.
trans-unit.target: By default, the Server Manager user interface (UI) allows you to setup columns up to 8 disks.

trans-unit.source: But if you have more than 8 disks, you need to use PowerShell to create the volume and also specify the number of columns manually.
trans-unit.target: But if you have more than 8 disks, you need to use PowerShell to create the volume and also specify the number of columns manually.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the Server Manager UI continues to use 8 columns even though you have more disks.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the Server Manager UI continues to use 8 columns even though you have more disks.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you have 32 disks in a single stripe set, you should specify 32 columns.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you have 32 disks in a single stripe set, you should specify 32 columns.

trans-unit.source: You can use the *NumberOfColumns* parameter of the [New-VirtualDisk](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh848643.aspx) PowerShell cmdlet to specify the number of columns used by the virtual disk.
trans-unit.target: You can use the *NumberOfColumns* parameter of the [New-VirtualDisk](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh848643.aspx) PowerShell cmdlet to specify the number of columns used by the virtual disk.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Storage Spaces Overview](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj822938.aspx) and [Storage Spaces Frequently Asked Questions](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/11382.storage-spaces-frequently-asked-questions-faq.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Storage Spaces Overview](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj822938.aspx) and [Storage Spaces Frequently Asked Questions](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/11382.storage-spaces-frequently-asked-questions-faq.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Avoid adding DS-series VMs to an existing cloud service that includes non-DS-series VMs.
trans-unit.target: Avoid adding DS-series VMs to an existing cloud service that includes non-DS-series VMs.

trans-unit.source: A possible workaround is to migrate your existing VHDs to a new cloud service running only DS-series VMs.
trans-unit.target: A possible workaround is to migrate your existing VHDs to a new cloud service running only DS-series VMs.

trans-unit.source: If you want to retain the same virtual IP address (VIP) for the new cloud service that hosts your DS-series VMs, use the [Reserved IP Addresses](virtual-networks-configure-vnet-to-vnet-connection.md) feature.
trans-unit.target: If you want to retain the same virtual IP address (VIP) for the new cloud service that hosts your DS-series VMs, use the [Reserved IP Addresses](virtual-networks-configure-vnet-to-vnet-connection.md) feature.

trans-unit.source: GS-series VMs can be added to an existing cloud service running only G-series VMs.
trans-unit.target: GS-series VMs can be added to an existing cloud service running only G-series VMs.

trans-unit.source: The DS-series of Azure virtual machines can be configured to use an operating system (OS) disk hosted either on a Standard Storage account or on a Premium Storage account.
trans-unit.target: The DS-series of Azure virtual machines can be configured to use an operating system (OS) disk hosted either on a Standard Storage account or on a Premium Storage account.

trans-unit.source: If you use the OS disk only for booting, you may consider using a Standard Storage based OS disk.
trans-unit.target: If you use the OS disk only for booting, you may consider using a Standard Storage based OS disk.

trans-unit.source: This provides cost benefits and similar performance results similar to the Premium Storage after booting up.
trans-unit.target: This provides cost benefits and similar performance results similar to the Premium Storage after booting up.

trans-unit.source: If you perform any additional tasks on the OS disk other than booting, use Premium Storage as it provides better performance results.
trans-unit.target: If you perform any additional tasks on the OS disk other than booting, use Premium Storage as it provides better performance results.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your application reads/writes from/to the OS disk, using Premium Storage based OS disk provides better performance for your VM.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your application reads/writes from/to the OS disk, using Premium Storage based OS disk provides better performance for your VM.

trans-unit.source: You can use [Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI)](../xplat-cli.md) with Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: You can use [Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI)](../xplat-cli.md) with Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: To change the cache policy on one of your disks using Azure CLI, run the following command:
trans-unit.target: To change the cache policy on one of your disks using Azure CLI, run the following command:

trans-unit.source: Note that the caching policy options can be ReadOnly, None, or ReadWrite.
trans-unit.target: Note that the caching policy options can be ReadOnly, None, or ReadWrite.

trans-unit.source: For more options, see the help by running the following command:
trans-unit.target: For more options, see the help by running the following command:

trans-unit.source: Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage
trans-unit.target: Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage

trans-unit.source: When you provision a disk against a Premium Storage account, how much input/output operations per second (IOPS) and throughput (bandwidth) it can get depends on the size of the disk.
trans-unit.target: When you provision a disk against a Premium Storage account, how much input/output operations per second (IOPS) and throughput (bandwidth) it can get depends on the size of the disk.

trans-unit.source: Currently, there are three types of Premium Storage disks: P10, P20, and P30.
trans-unit.target: Currently, there are three types of Premium Storage disks: P10, P20, and P30.

trans-unit.source: Each one has specific limits for IOPS and throughput as specified in the following table:
trans-unit.target: Each one has specific limits for IOPS and throughput as specified in the following table:

trans-unit.source: Premium Storage Disk Type
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage Disk Type

trans-unit.source: Disk size
trans-unit.target: Disk size

trans-unit.source: 128 GiB
trans-unit.target: 128 GiB

trans-unit.source: 512 GiB
trans-unit.target: 512 GiB

trans-unit.source: 1024 GiB (1 TB)
trans-unit.target: 1024 GiB (1 TB)

trans-unit.source: IOPS per disk
trans-unit.target: IOPS per disk

trans-unit.source: Throughput per disk
trans-unit.target: Throughput per disk

trans-unit.source: 100 MB per second *
trans-unit.target: 100 MB per second *

trans-unit.source: 150 MB per second *
trans-unit.target: 150 MB per second *

trans-unit.source: 200 MB per second *
trans-unit.target: 200 MB per second *

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Make sure that there is sufficient bandwidth available on your VM to drive the disk traffic as explained in the [Using Premium Storage for Disks](#using-premium-storage-for-disks) section earlier in this article.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Make sure that there is sufficient bandwidth available on your VM to drive the disk traffic as explained in the [Using Premium Storage for Disks](#using-premium-storage-for-disks) section earlier in this article.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, your disk throughput and IOPS will be constrained to lower values based on the VM limits rather than the disk limits mentioned in the previous table.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, your disk throughput and IOPS will be constrained to lower values based on the VM limits rather than the disk limits mentioned in the previous table.

trans-unit.source: Azure maps the disk size (rounded up) to the nearest Premium Storage Disk option as specified in the table.
trans-unit.target: Azure maps the disk size (rounded up) to the nearest Premium Storage Disk option as specified in the table.

trans-unit.source: For example, a disk of size 100 GiB is classified as a P10 option and can perform up to 500 IO units per second, and with up to 100 MB per second throughput.
trans-unit.target: For example, a disk of size 100 GiB is classified as a P10 option and can perform up to 500 IO units per second, and with up to 100 MB per second throughput.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, a disk of size 400 GiB is classified as a P20 option, and can perform up to 2300 IO units per second and up to 150 MB per second throughput.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, a disk of size 400 GiB is classified as a P20 option, and can perform up to 2300 IO units per second and up to 150 MB per second throughput.

trans-unit.source: The input/output (I/O) unit size is 256 KB.
trans-unit.target: The input/output (I/O) unit size is 256 KB.

trans-unit.source: If the data being transferred is less than 256 KB, it is considered a single I/O unit.
trans-unit.target: If the data being transferred is less than 256 KB, it is considered a single I/O unit.

trans-unit.source: The larger I/O sizes are counted as multiple I/Os of size 256 KB.
trans-unit.target: The larger I/O sizes are counted as multiple I/Os of size 256 KB.

trans-unit.source: For example, 1100 KB I/O is counted as five I/O units.
trans-unit.target: For example, 1100 KB I/O is counted as five I/O units.

trans-unit.source: The throughput limit includes writes to the disk as well as reads from that disk that are not served from the cache.
trans-unit.target: The throughput limit includes writes to the disk as well as reads from that disk that are not served from the cache.

trans-unit.source: For example, the sum of non-cache reads and writes should be smaller or equal to 100 MB per second for a P10 disk.
trans-unit.target: For example, the sum of non-cache reads and writes should be smaller or equal to 100 MB per second for a P10 disk.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, a single P10 disk can have either 100 MB per second of non-cache reads or 100 MB per second of writes, or 60 MB per second of reads with 40 MB per second of writes as an example.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, a single P10 disk can have either 100 MB per second of non-cache reads or 100 MB per second of writes, or 60 MB per second of reads with 40 MB per second of writes as an example.

trans-unit.source: When you create your disks in Azure, select the most appropriate Premium Storage disk offering based on the needs of your application in terms of capacity, performance, scalability, and peak loads.
trans-unit.target: When you create your disks in Azure, select the most appropriate Premium Storage disk offering based on the needs of your application in terms of capacity, performance, scalability, and peak loads.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can easily increase the size of existing disks.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can easily increase the size of existing disks.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you wish to increase the size of a 30 GB disk to 128GB or to 1 TB.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you wish to increase the size of a 30 GB disk to 128GB or to 1 TB.

trans-unit.source: Or, if you wish to convert your P20 disk to a P30 disk because you need more capacity or more IOPS and throughput.
trans-unit.target: Or, if you wish to convert your P20 disk to a P30 disk because you need more capacity or more IOPS and throughput.

trans-unit.source: You can expand the disk using “Update-AzureDisk” PowerShell commandlet with “-ResizedSizeInGB” property.
trans-unit.target: You can expand the disk using “Update-AzureDisk” PowerShell commandlet with “-ResizedSizeInGB” property.

trans-unit.source: For performing this action, disk needs to be detached from the VM or the VM needs to be stopped.
trans-unit.target: For performing this action, disk needs to be detached from the VM or the VM needs to be stopped.

trans-unit.source: The following table describes the scalability targets for Premium storage accounts:
trans-unit.target: The following table describes the scalability targets for Premium storage accounts:

trans-unit.source: Total Account Capacity
trans-unit.target: Total Account Capacity

trans-unit.source: Total Bandwidth for a Locally Redundant Storage Account
trans-unit.target: Total Bandwidth for a Locally Redundant Storage Account

trans-unit.source: Disk capacity: 35 TB
trans-unit.target: Disk capacity: 35 TB

trans-unit.source: Snapshot capacity: 10 TB
trans-unit.target: Snapshot capacity: 10 TB

trans-unit.source: Up to 50 gigabits per second for Inbound + Outbound
trans-unit.target: Up to 50 gigabits per second for Inbound + Outbound

trans-unit.source: Inbound refers to all data (requests) being sent to a storage account.
trans-unit.target: Inbound refers to all data (requests) being sent to a storage account.

trans-unit.source: Outbound refers to all data (responses) being received from a storage account.
trans-unit.target: Outbound refers to all data (responses) being received from a storage account.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn249410.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn249410.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Throttling when using Premium Storage
trans-unit.target: Throttling when using Premium Storage

trans-unit.source: You may see throttling if your application’s IOPS or throughput exceed the allocated limits for a Premium Storage disk or if your total disk traffic across all disks on the VM exceeds the disk bandwidth limit available for the VM.
trans-unit.target: You may see throttling if your application’s IOPS or throughput exceed the allocated limits for a Premium Storage disk or if your total disk traffic across all disks on the VM exceeds the disk bandwidth limit available for the VM.

trans-unit.source: To avoid throttling, we recommend that you limit the number of pending I/O requests for disk based on the scalability and performance targets for the disk you have provisioned and based on the disk bandwidth available to the VM.
trans-unit.target: To avoid throttling, we recommend that you limit the number of pending I/O requests for disk based on the scalability and performance targets for the disk you have provisioned and based on the disk bandwidth available to the VM.

trans-unit.source: Your application can achieve the lowest latency when it is designed to avoid throttling.
trans-unit.target: Your application can achieve the lowest latency when it is designed to avoid throttling.

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, if the number of pending I/O requests for the disk is too small, your application cannot take advantage of the maximum IOPS and throughput levels that are available to the disk.
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, if the number of pending I/O requests for the disk is too small, your application cannot take advantage of the maximum IOPS and throughput levels that are available to the disk.

trans-unit.source: The following examples demonstrate how to calculate the throttling levels:
trans-unit.target: The following examples demonstrate how to calculate the throttling levels:

trans-unit.source: Example 1:
trans-unit.target: Example 1:

trans-unit.source: Your application has done 495 I/Os of 16 KB disk size (, which is equal to 495 I/O Units) in one second on a P10 disk.
trans-unit.target: Your application has done 495 I/Os of 16 KB disk size (, which is equal to 495 I/O Units) in one second on a P10 disk.

trans-unit.source: If you try a 2 MB I/O in the same second, the total of I/O units is equal to 495 + 8.
trans-unit.target: If you try a 2 MB I/O in the same second, the total of I/O units is equal to 495 + 8.

trans-unit.source: This is because 2 MB I/O results in 2048 KB / 256 KB = 8 I/O Units when the I/O unit size is 256 KB.
trans-unit.target: This is because 2 MB I/O results in 2048 KB / 256 KB = 8 I/O Units when the I/O unit size is 256 KB.

trans-unit.source: Since the sum of 495 + 8 exceeds the 500 IOPS limit for the disk, throttling occurs.
trans-unit.target: Since the sum of 495 + 8 exceeds the 500 IOPS limit for the disk, throttling occurs.

trans-unit.source: Note:
trans-unit.target: Note:

trans-unit.source: All calculations are based on the I/O unit size of 256 KB.
trans-unit.target: All calculations are based on the I/O unit size of 256 KB.

trans-unit.source: Example 2:
trans-unit.target: Example 2:

trans-unit.source: Your application has done 400 I/Os of 256 KB disk size on a P10 disk.
trans-unit.target: Your application has done 400 I/Os of 256 KB disk size on a P10 disk.

trans-unit.source: The total bandwidth consumed is (400 * 256) / 1024 = 100 MB/sec.
trans-unit.target: The total bandwidth consumed is (400 * 256) / 1024 = 100 MB/sec.

trans-unit.source: Note that 100 MB per second is the throughput limit of a P10 disk.
trans-unit.target: Note that 100 MB per second is the throughput limit of a P10 disk.

trans-unit.source: If your application tries to perform more I/O in that second, it gets throttled because it exceeds the allocated limit.
trans-unit.target: If your application tries to perform more I/O in that second, it gets throttled because it exceeds the allocated limit.

trans-unit.source: Example 3:
trans-unit.target: Example 3:

trans-unit.source: You have a DS4 VM with two P30 disks attached.
trans-unit.target: You have a DS4 VM with two P30 disks attached.

trans-unit.source: Each P30 disk is capable of 200 MB per second throughput.
trans-unit.target: Each P30 disk is capable of 200 MB per second throughput.

trans-unit.source: However, a DS4 VM has a total disk bandwidth capacity of 256 MB per second.
trans-unit.target: However, a DS4 VM has a total disk bandwidth capacity of 256 MB per second.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, you cannot drive the attached disks to the maximum throughput on this DS4 VM at the same time.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, you cannot drive the attached disks to the maximum throughput on this DS4 VM at the same time.

trans-unit.source: To resolve this, you can sustain traffic of 200 MB per second on one disk and 56 MB per second on the other disk.
trans-unit.target: To resolve this, you can sustain traffic of 200 MB per second on one disk and 56 MB per second on the other disk.

trans-unit.source: If the sum of your disk traffic goes over 256 MB per second, the disk traffic gets throttled.
trans-unit.target: If the sum of your disk traffic goes over 256 MB per second, the disk traffic gets throttled.

trans-unit.source: Note:
trans-unit.target: Note:

trans-unit.source: If the disk traffic mostly consists of small I/O sizes, it is highly likely that your application will hit the IOPS limit before the throughput limit.
trans-unit.target: If the disk traffic mostly consists of small I/O sizes, it is highly likely that your application will hit the IOPS limit before the throughput limit.

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, if the disk traffic mostly consists of large I/O sizes, it is highly likely that your application will hit the throughput limit instead of the IOPS limit.
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, if the disk traffic mostly consists of large I/O sizes, it is highly likely that your application will hit the throughput limit instead of the IOPS limit.

trans-unit.source: You can maximize your application’s IOPS and throughput capacity by using optimal I/O sizes and also by limiting the number of pending I/O requests for disk.
trans-unit.target: You can maximize your application’s IOPS and throughput capacity by using optimal I/O sizes and also by limiting the number of pending I/O requests for disk.

trans-unit.source: Snapshots and Copy Blob when using Premium Storage
trans-unit.target: Snapshots and Copy Blob when using Premium Storage

trans-unit.source: You can create a snapshot for Premium Storage in the same way as you create a snapshot when using Standard Storage.
trans-unit.target: You can create a snapshot for Premium Storage in the same way as you create a snapshot when using Standard Storage.

trans-unit.source: Since Premium Storage is locally redundant, we recommend that you create snapshots and then copy those snapshots to a geo-redundant standard storage account.
trans-unit.target: Since Premium Storage is locally redundant, we recommend that you create snapshots and then copy those snapshots to a geo-redundant standard storage account.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure Storage Redundancy Options](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn727290.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure Storage Redundancy Options](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn727290.aspx).

trans-unit.source: If a disk is attached to a VM, certain API operations are not permitted on the page blob backing the disk.
trans-unit.target: If a disk is attached to a VM, certain API operations are not permitted on the page blob backing the disk.

trans-unit.source: For example, you cannot perform a [Copy Blob](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd894037.aspx) operation on that blob as long as the disk is attached to a VM.
trans-unit.target: For example, you cannot perform a [Copy Blob](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd894037.aspx) operation on that blob as long as the disk is attached to a VM.

trans-unit.source: Instead, first create a snapshot of that blob by using the [Snapshot Blob](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee691971.aspx) REST API method, and then perform the [Copy Blob](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd894037.aspx) of the snapshot to copy the attached disk.
trans-unit.target: Instead, first create a snapshot of that blob by using the [Snapshot Blob](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee691971.aspx) REST API method, and then perform the [Copy Blob](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd894037.aspx) of the snapshot to copy the attached disk.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can detach the disk and then perform any necessary operations on the underlying blob.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can detach the disk and then perform any necessary operations on the underlying blob.

trans-unit.source: Important Notes:
trans-unit.target: Important Notes:

trans-unit.source: The number of snapshots for a single blob is limited to 100.
trans-unit.target: The number of snapshots for a single blob is limited to 100.

trans-unit.source: A snapshot can be taken every 10 minutes at most.
trans-unit.target: A snapshot can be taken every 10 minutes at most.

trans-unit.source: The maximum capacity for snapshots per Premium Storage account is 10 TB.
trans-unit.target: The maximum capacity for snapshots per Premium Storage account is 10 TB.

trans-unit.source: Note that snapshot capacity refers to the total amount of data in snapshots only, and does not include data in the base blob.
trans-unit.target: Note that snapshot capacity refers to the total amount of data in snapshots only, and does not include data in the base blob.

trans-unit.source: To maintain geo-redundant copies of your snapshots, you can copy snapshots from a premium storage account to a geo-redundant standard storage account by using AzCopy or Copy Blob.
trans-unit.target: To maintain geo-redundant copies of your snapshots, you can copy snapshots from a premium storage account to a geo-redundant standard storage account by using AzCopy or Copy Blob.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to use AzCopy with Microsoft Azure Storage](storage-use-azcopy.md) and [Copy Blob](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd894037.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to use AzCopy with Microsoft Azure Storage](storage-use-azcopy.md) and [Copy Blob](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd894037.aspx).

trans-unit.source: For detailed information on performing REST operations against page blobs in Premium Storage accounts, see [Using Blob Service Operations with Azure Premium Storage](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521969) in the MSDN library.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information on performing REST operations against page blobs in Premium Storage accounts, see [Using Blob Service Operations with Azure Premium Storage](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521969) in the MSDN library.

trans-unit.source: Using Linux VMs with Premium Storage
trans-unit.target: Using Linux VMs with Premium Storage

trans-unit.source: Please refer to important instructions below for configuring your Linux VMs on Premium Storage:
trans-unit.target: Please refer to important instructions below for configuring your Linux VMs on Premium Storage:

trans-unit.source: For all Premium Storage disks with cache setting as either “ReadOnly” or “None”, you must disable “barriers” while mounting the file system in order to achieve the scalability targets for Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: For all Premium Storage disks with cache setting as either “ReadOnly” or “None”, you must disable “barriers” while mounting the file system in order to achieve the scalability targets for Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: You do not need barriers for this scenario because the writes to Premium Storage backed disks are durable for these cache settings.
trans-unit.target: You do not need barriers for this scenario because the writes to Premium Storage backed disks are durable for these cache settings.

trans-unit.source: When the write request successfully completes, data has been written to the persistent store.
trans-unit.target: When the write request successfully completes, data has been written to the persistent store.

trans-unit.source: Please use the following methods for disabling “barriers” depending on your file system:
trans-unit.target: Please use the following methods for disabling “barriers” depending on your file system:

trans-unit.source: If you use **reiserFS**, disable barriers using the mount option “barrier=none” (For enabling barriers, use “barrier=flush”)
trans-unit.target: If you use **reiserFS**, disable barriers using the mount option “barrier=none” (For enabling barriers, use “barrier=flush”)

trans-unit.source: If you use **ext3/ext4**, disable barriers using the mount option “barrier=0” (For enabling barriers, use “barrier=1”)
trans-unit.target: If you use **ext3/ext4**, disable barriers using the mount option “barrier=0” (For enabling barriers, use “barrier=1”)

trans-unit.source: If you use **XFS**, disable barriers using the mount option “nobarrier” (For enabling barriers, use the option “barrier”)
trans-unit.target: If you use **XFS**, disable barriers using the mount option “nobarrier” (For enabling barriers, use the option “barrier”)

trans-unit.source: For Premium Storage disks with cache setting “ReadWrite”, barriers should be enabled for durability of writes.
trans-unit.target: For Premium Storage disks with cache setting “ReadWrite”, barriers should be enabled for durability of writes.

trans-unit.source: Following are the Linux Distributions that we validated with Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: Following are the Linux Distributions that we validated with Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you upgrade your VMs to at least one of these versions (or later) for better performance and stability with Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you upgrade your VMs to at least one of these versions (or later) for better performance and stability with Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: Also, some of the versions require the latest LIS (Linux Integration Services v4.0 for Microsoft Azure).
trans-unit.target: Also, some of the versions require the latest LIS (Linux Integration Services v4.0 for Microsoft Azure).

trans-unit.source: Please follow the link provided below for download and installation.
trans-unit.target: Please follow the link provided below for download and installation.

trans-unit.source: We will continue to add more images to the list as we complete additional validations.
trans-unit.target: We will continue to add more images to the list as we complete additional validations.

trans-unit.source: Please note, our validations showed that performance varies for these images, and it also depends on workload characteristics and settings on the images.
trans-unit.target: Please note, our validations showed that performance varies for these images, and it also depends on workload characteristics and settings on the images.

trans-unit.source: Different images are tuned for different kinds of workload.
trans-unit.target: Different images are tuned for different kinds of workload.

trans-unit.target: LIS Drivers for Openlogic CentOS

trans-unit.target: Customers running OpenLogic CentOS VMs should run the following command to install the latest drivers:

trans-unit.source: Pricing and Billing when using Premium Storage
trans-unit.target: Pricing and Billing when using Premium Storage

trans-unit.source: When using Premium Storage, the following billing considerations apply:
trans-unit.target: When using Premium Storage, the following billing considerations apply:

trans-unit.source: Billing for a Premium Storage disk depends on the provisioned size of the disk.
trans-unit.target: Billing for a Premium Storage disk depends on the provisioned size of the disk.

trans-unit.source: Azure maps the disk size (rounded up) to the nearest Premium Storage Disk option as specified in the table given in the [Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage](#scalability-and-performance-targets-when-using-premium-storage) section.
trans-unit.target: Azure maps the disk size (rounded up) to the nearest Premium Storage Disk option as specified in the table given in the [Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage](#scalability-and-performance-targets-when-using-premium-storage) section.

trans-unit.source: Billing for any provisioned disk is prorated hourly using the monthly price for the Premium Storage offer.
trans-unit.target: Billing for any provisioned disk is prorated hourly using the monthly price for the Premium Storage offer.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you provisioned a P10 disk and deleted it after 20 hours, you are billed for the P10 offering prorated to 20 hours.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you provisioned a P10 disk and deleted it after 20 hours, you are billed for the P10 offering prorated to 20 hours.

trans-unit.source: This is regardless of the amount of actual data written to the disk or the IOPS/throughput used.
trans-unit.target: This is regardless of the amount of actual data written to the disk or the IOPS/throughput used.

trans-unit.source: Snapshots on Premium Storage are billed for the additional capacity used by the snapshots.
trans-unit.target: Snapshots on Premium Storage are billed for the additional capacity used by the snapshots.

trans-unit.source: For information on snapshots, see [Creating a Snapshot of a Blob](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh488361.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For information on snapshots, see [Creating a Snapshot of a Blob](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh488361.aspx).

trans-unit.source: [Outbound data transfers](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/data-transfers/) (data going out of Azure data centers) incur billing for bandwidth usage.
trans-unit.target: [Outbound data transfers](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/data-transfers/) (data going out of Azure data centers) incur billing for bandwidth usage.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information on pricing for Premium Storage, DS-series VMs and GS-series VMs, see:
trans-unit.target: For detailed information on pricing for Premium Storage, DS-series VMs and GS-series VMs, see:

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage Pricing
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage Pricing

trans-unit.source: Virtual Machines Pricing
trans-unit.target: Virtual Machines Pricing

trans-unit.source: Create and use a Premium Storage account for a virtual machine data disk
trans-unit.target: Create and use a Premium Storage account for a virtual machine data disk

trans-unit.source: This section demonstrates how to create a Premium Storage account using the Azure Preview Portal, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI).
trans-unit.target: This section demonstrates how to create a Premium Storage account using the Azure Preview Portal, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI).

trans-unit.source: In addition, it demonstrates a sample use case for premium storage accounts: creating a virtual machine and attaching a data disk to a virtual machine when using Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: In addition, it demonstrates a sample use case for premium storage accounts: creating a virtual machine and attaching a data disk to a virtual machine when using Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure virtual machine using Premium Storage via the Azure Preview Portal
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure virtual machine using Premium Storage via the Azure Preview Portal

trans-unit.source: This section shows how to create a Premium Storage account using the Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: This section shows how to create a Premium Storage account using the Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the [Azure Preview Portal](https://portal.azure.com/).
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the [Azure Preview Portal](https://portal.azure.com/).

trans-unit.source: Check out the [Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/) offer if you do not have a subscription yet.
trans-unit.target: Check out the [Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/) offer if you do not have a subscription yet.

trans-unit.source: On the Hub menu, click **New**.
trans-unit.target: On the Hub menu, click **New**.

trans-unit.source: Under **New**, click **Everything**.
trans-unit.target: Under **New**, click **Everything**.

trans-unit.source: Select **Storage, cache, +backup**.
trans-unit.target: Select **Storage, cache, +backup**.

trans-unit.source: From there, click **Storage** and then click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: From there, click **Storage** and then click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: On the Storage Account blade, type a name for your storage account.
trans-unit.target: On the Storage Account blade, type a name for your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Click **Pricing Tier**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Pricing Tier**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Recommended pricing tiers** blade, click **Browse All Pricing Tiers**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Recommended pricing tiers** blade, click **Browse All Pricing Tiers**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Choose your pricing tier** blade, choose **Premium Locally Redundant**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Choose your pricing tier** blade, choose **Premium Locally Redundant**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Select**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Select**.

trans-unit.source: Note that the **Storage account** blade shows **Standard-GRS** as the **Pricing Tier** by default.
trans-unit.target: Note that the **Storage account** blade shows **Standard-GRS** as the **Pricing Tier** by default.

trans-unit.source: After you click **Select**, the **Pricing Tier** is shown as **Premium-LRS**.
trans-unit.target: After you click **Select**, the **Pricing Tier** is shown as **Premium-LRS**.

trans-unit.source: Pricing Tier
trans-unit.target: Pricing Tier

trans-unit.source: On the **Storage Account** blade, keep the default values for **Resource Group**, **Subscription**, **Location**, and **Diagnostics**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Storage Account** blade, keep the default values for **Resource Group**, **Subscription**, **Location**, and **Diagnostics**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: For a complete walk-through inside an Azure environment, see [Create a Virtual Machine Running Windows in the Azure Preview Portal](../virtual-machines-windows-tutorial-azure-preview.md).
trans-unit.target: For a complete walk-through inside an Azure environment, see [Create a Virtual Machine Running Windows in the Azure Preview Portal](../virtual-machines-windows-tutorial-azure-preview.md).

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure virtual machine using Premium Storage via Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure virtual machine using Premium Storage via Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: This PowerShell example shows how to create a new Premium Storage account and attach a data disk that uses that account to a new Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This PowerShell example shows how to create a new Premium Storage account and attach a data disk that uses that account to a new Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Setup your PowerShell environment by following the steps given at [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../install-configure-powershell.md).
trans-unit.target: Setup your PowerShell environment by following the steps given at [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../install-configure-powershell.md).

trans-unit.source: Start the PowerShell console, connect to your subscription, and run the following PowerShell cmdlet in the console window.
trans-unit.target: Start the PowerShell console, connect to your subscription, and run the following PowerShell cmdlet in the console window.

trans-unit.source: As seen in this PowerShell statement, you need to specify the **Type** parameter as **Premium_LRS** when you create a premium storage account.
trans-unit.target: As seen in this PowerShell statement, you need to specify the **Type** parameter as **Premium_LRS** when you create a premium storage account.

trans-unit.source: Next, create a new DS-Series VM and specify that you want Premium Storage by running the following PowerShell cmdlets in the console window.
trans-unit.target: Next, create a new DS-Series VM and specify that you want Premium Storage by running the following PowerShell cmdlets in the console window.

trans-unit.source: You can create a GS-series VM using the same steps.
trans-unit.target: You can create a GS-series VM using the same steps.

trans-unit.source: Specify the appropriate VM size in the commands.
trans-unit.target: Specify the appropriate VM size in the commands.

trans-unit.source: For e.g. Standard_GS2:
trans-unit.target: For e.g. Standard_GS2:

trans-unit.source: If you want more disk space for your VM, attach a new data disk to an existing DS-series VM or GS-series VM after it is created by running the following PowerShell cmdlets in the console window:
trans-unit.target: If you want more disk space for your VM, attach a new data disk to an existing DS-series VM or GS-series VM after it is created by running the following PowerShell cmdlets in the console window:

trans-unit.source: The [Azure Commnand-Line Interface](../xplat-cli.md)(Azure CLI) provides a provides a set of open source, cross-platform commands for working with the Azure Platform.
trans-unit.target: The [Azure Commnand-Line Interface](../xplat-cli.md)(Azure CLI) provides a provides a set of open source, cross-platform commands for working with the Azure Platform.

trans-unit.source: The following examples show how to use Azure CLI (version 0.8.14 and later) to create a premium storage account, a new virtual machine, and attach a new data disk from a Premium Storage account.
